messageBody:
Agreed, in most case of Singletons, they are created, not because there
'has to be no more than one', but because the static (aka global) access
method makes it 'easier' and 'cleaner' to use through out the code base.
These 'benefits' are often misguided and can be better solved using the
'just create one' approach

Andrew

On 7/30/07, Nat Pryce <nat.pryce@...> wrote:
>
> The simplest approach I've found is that if there is need for only one
> instance of some class in a system, to just create only one instance of
> that
> type.
>
> Adding extra code just to stop me creating more than one is always, in my
> experience, counter-productive. It's more code to write, test and maintain
> and it gets in the way when I do need to create more than one. For
> example,
> in unit tests. Or when requirements change.
>
> --Nat
>



>
